entry.title: What we know now about how ancient archers made their bows
entry.summary:
Fresh analysis of a collection of sinew bowstrings and arrow fragments is rewriting the history of Neolithic archery. The artifacts recovered in the shelter of the Cave of the Bats, AlbunÌƒol, in Spain, were originally discovered by miners in the 19th century. These finds were recently analyzed by a team of archaeologists using an unprecedented combination of microscopy and biomolecular methods.
Preserved for more than seven millennia, the bowstrings were revealed to pre-date the weaponry of OÌˆtzi, the ice mummy discovered in the OÌˆtztal Alps, by more than 2,000 yearsâ€”pushing back the timeline for animal-derived bowstrings in present-day Europe. The groundbreaking study, published in Scientific Reports in 2024, offers startling new insights into the technical mastery of Neolithic archeâ€¦

entry.title: Did the ancient Romans really abandon people with disabilities?
entry.summary:
Early Roman Empire depiction of a Freedman and Freedwoman, 30-15 BCE. British Museum, London, UK. New evidence suggests that ancient Roman attitudes towards people with disabilities were more nuanced than previously known. New archaeological evidence is helping rewrite old myths about disabled people in the ancient world.
There is a popular perception that the ancient Greeks and Romans were so focused on strength and power that they abandoned disabled infants and community members to die. According to the first-century CE philosopher and biographer Plutarch, the Spartans would bring their newborns to a council of elders for assessment. Those babies who were deemed to be â€œlowborn or deformedâ€ were left outside to die.
For nearly two millennia since, there has been a pervasive sâ€¦

entry.title: 6 festive train rides in the U.S.
entry.summary:
Christmas at Cass is held each December at the Cass Scenic Railroad. The steam-powered journey with decorated and heated coaches travels along the scenic Greenbrier River. From West Virginia to California, passengers board classic train carriages decked out in lights and garland, offering a unique way to celebrate the holiday season.
A train ride can be a magical experience, whether itâ€™s anÂ Amtrak rideÂ or an excursionÂ around the world. When it incorporates holiday trimmings and festive lights, set against a wintry backdrop, thatâ€™s a train ride that becomes instantly memorable, with the potential to become an annual family tradition.Â
The success of Chris Van Allsburgâ€™s book The Polar Express (1985) sparked interest in a night train journey to the North Pole among adults and châ€¦

entry.title: How to Investigate Pharmaceutical Oligopolies
entry.summary: At GIJC25, Peruvian investigative journalist Fabiola Torres showed reporters how to uncover the systems behind pharma monopolies, and how to connect market structures to human impact.

entry.title: When did cats become domesticated?
entry.summary:
An African wildcat (Felis lybica) rests on a rock in Kruger National Park, South Africa. A new study overturns previous findings that domestic cats originated thousands of years earlier.
From urban bodegas to remote islands, cats are everywhere.Â But determining where and when humans first adoptedÂ feral felinesÂ has proven tricky.Â
So far, scientists have focused on Africa and the Middle East, where the wildcats that gave rise to the modern pets are found. Archeological finds and recent work on ancient genetics has led many researchers to hypothesize that stone age farmers domesticated cats nearly 10,000 years ago in the Middle East andÂ brought the rodent-killing kitties along with them as they subsequently moved into Europe.
Now, a new DNA analysisÂ ofÂ a sprawling set of anâ€¦

entry.title: Mass displacement, trafficking fears deepen crisis in Sudanâ€™s El Fasher
entry.summary: The humanitarian crisis in Sudanâ€™s El Fasher remains dire as mass displacement accelerates and aid access stays restricted, amid warnings of widespread trafficking, sexual violence and the recruitment of children.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: A decisive turning point: Setting global industry on a fairer, greener path towards economic growth
entry.summary: The world moved closer to ensuring that industrial development is a net positive for people and the planet on Thursday, with the adoption of the Riyadh Declaration on the closing day of the Global Industry Summit, a week-long UN event in the Saudi capital.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: These Nepalese homestays are transforming Himalayan travel
entry.summary:
Kamala Rai is one of many locals welcoming visitors into her home through community homestays in Sipting. Nepal is famed for its high-altitude trekking routes, drawing adventurers to scale the soaring peaks of Everest and Annapurna â€” but for those seeking a deeper connection to local life, homestays invite visitors into the family fold.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
A teenage boy strides across the courtyard, casually scooping a chicken from the ground and tucking it under his arm like a plumed designer clutch bag. Shortly after, the same bird makes a surprise reappearance on my plate â€” charred feathers and all. Itâ€™s part of an elaborate feast prepared by Kamala Rai, my host for the next few days in Sipting, a village in the mist-shrouded hâ€¦

entry.title: Discover Northern Norway through the 8 SÃ¡mi seasons
entry.summary:
In the spectacular SÃ¡pmi region â€” which spans Northern Norway, as well as parts of Sweden, Finland and Russia â€” every month brings in something new. The regionâ€™s Indigenous SÃ¡mi people separate the year into eight unique seasons, each marking an important time for those working in farming, fishing and reindeer herding. For travellers visiting, seasonal highlights include chasing the Northern Lights, snowmobiling, hiking and dog sledding. Read on to discover all there is to do in the northernmost part of Norway during each distinct SÃ¡mi season.
From December to February, Finnmark County â€” the northernmost and easternmost county in Norway â€” settles into the coldest days and longest nights. This time of year, known as dÃ¡lvi, is the ideal time to search for the Northern Lights. There isâ€¦

entry.title: Sharks are thriving in some marine parksâ€”but not others. Why?
entry.summary:
Seen from above the ocean surface, the tiny island of Roca Partida in Mexico's Revillagigedo Islands looks like two small peaks jutting out from the water. Underwater, this remote island hosts a rich marine habitat home to whitetip reef sharks, Pacific creolefish, barberfish, and Moorish idols. A study of marine parks spanning Mexico to Ecuador found key differences that allow ecosystems to flourish.
As Simon McKinley dropped down in the water, everything went dark. Heâ€™d seen sharks from the surface but nowâ€”gradually descending on his scuba diveâ€”so many scalloped hammerheads were schooling together that they were blocking the sunlight. â€œYou couldn't turn anywhere without seeing a shark,â€ he says.
McKinley, a spatial ecologist at the Charles Darwin Foundation, was surveying shaâ€¦

entry.title: These are the most delicious cities on Earth
entry.summary:
The sun rises quickly in the Sonoran desert. By 6 a.m., the air is already scorched and smoky, infused with mesquite from a bakerâ€™s wood-fired oven. The loaves rise slowly, made from heritage wheat first planted here centuries ago. Tearing open the crust, its nutty sweetness carries both flavor and memory. Each grain remembers a long line of farmers, floods, and hands that refused to let it disappear. This is Tucsonâ€”the first American city to earn UNESCOâ€™s title of City of Gastronomy.
This title has been bestowed to only 56 cities in the world, special places which celebrate how people grow, share, and sustain food, proving that food heritage is just as vital as language or architecture.Â
UNESCOâ€™s City of Gastronomy title recognizes how a city feeds its soul. To earn it, a place â€¦

entry.title: Why trains might be the best way to see America
entry.summary:
Train travel is a great way to explore America, including visiting some national parks. Hereâ€™s how to swap highway traffic jams for panoramic views and ride to some of the countryâ€™s most beautiful natural destinations.
Most people see the open road when they think of visiting all 50 states and many national parks. But what if your plans donâ€™t involve a long cross-country road trip? Itâ€™s possibleâ€”and potentially easier, more environmentally friendly, and more funâ€”to go by rail.Â
Alicia Rovey of the All Fifty Club, a group of travel enthusiasts who want to visit all 50 states, visited five states with her family on Amtrakâ€™s Southwest Chief, which runs between Chicago and Los Angeles. Their trip took them from Kansas City, Missouri, to Kingman, Arizona. â€œMany routes travel acroâ€¦

entry.title: How a doomed bridge became an unlikely reef
Indigenous tourism is thriving in Canadaâ€”hereâ€™s why
entry.summary:
Indigenous tourism is growing. The World Travel & Tourism CouncilÂ projects that it will add $67 billionÂ to the global travel economy by 2034. The world leader is Canada, where 1.8 million people identify as First Nations, Inuit, or MÃ©tis, the countryâ€™s three primary groups of native-born people. According to aÂ report by the Conference Board of Canada,Â in 2023, Indigenous tourism contributed $1.2 billion in revenue, nearly twice that in 2017, and supported more than 50,000 jobs across the country.Â
HX Expeditionâ€™sÂ Northwest Passage & Arctic Canada cruiseÂ is the newest example of the rising tide of Indigenous tourism. In a radical revamp of the traditional cruise model, â€œThrough the Arctic Labyrinthâ€ not only highlights the raw beauty of lesser-known places but also serves to highlight â€¦

entry.title: Are these sharks 'playing' with pool toys?
entry.summary:
A California horn shark (Heterodontus francisci) inspects a blue-and-yellow squid toy on the tank floor. New video shows sharks swimming through hoops, and picking them up with their noses. It sure looks like they are having fun. But researchers are divided. 
Scientists have no problem using the word â€œplayâ€ to describe dogs who fetch sticks or cats batting around yarn. But with sharks, itâ€™s a whole other ballgame.Â
A new studyÂ in the journalÂ Applied Animal Behavioral ScienceÂ describes sharks interacting with human toys in a way that resembles play, though the word â€œplayâ€ does not appear in the paper.Â
Video footage from the study shows sharks swimming through hoops, picking them up with their nose, and flicking the toys with their tails, and bumping or biting them. Lâ€¦

entry.title: Your body has a natural way of getting high
entry.summary:
When you think about the various systems in your body, the cardiovascular system, the immune system, the reproductive system, and the digestive system probably come to mind. The endocannabinoid system? Not so much. In fact, you may not even know that it exists.Â
The truth is, the endocannabinoid system (ECS, for short) is present in all human beings, as well as in rabbits, mice, dogs, and all other mammals, says Deepak Cyril Dâ€™Souza, professor of psychiatry and director of the Yale Center for the Science of Cannabis and Cannabinoids. â€œItâ€™s a natural communication system in the brain and body. We believe it plays an important role in homeostasisâ€”keeping things in balance.â€
The ECS wasnâ€™t discovered until 1990 when researchers were investigating the psychotropic actions of marijuanâ€¦

entry.title: Connecting to untapped potential and the strength of community in Hawaii
entry.summary:
National Geographic photographer Josh Cogan has always believed in the power of placeâ€”not just for what it reveals to us, but for what it unlocks within us. On Hawaiiâ€™s Big Island, he recently turned his lens toward Joey, a former first responder, father, and advocate. Joey lives with CIDP (chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy), a rare progressive autoimmune condition that affects the nerves and can impact mobility and sensation.
After years of navigating the uncertainty and frustrations that came with his changing body, Joey was ready for a journey from his hometown of Gate City, Virginia, to Hawaiiâ€™s Big Island.
Together with Josh, he explored the deep community connections on the Big Island. They visited O.K. Farms, a working farm where 'ulu (breadfruit) and kalo â€¦

entry.title: Why Ancient Egyptians needed the flooding of the Nile
entry.summary:
When Greek historian Herodotus visited Egypt around 450 B.C., he marveled at the countryâ€™s extraordinary natural wealth, famously writing, â€œEgypt is the gift of the Nile.â€ His words could not have been more accurate. Cities and settlements flourished along the banks of this great river that runs through a fertile valley. Without the life-giving waters of the Nile, Egypt would be nothing but desert.
In pharaonic times, Egypt was known as Kemet, meaning â€œblack land,â€ a reference to the dark, fertile silt deposited each year by the Nileâ€™s flood. This natural fertilizer nourished the land and made it possible to grow crops, supporting a dense population and prosperous cities. The flood was an annual summertime occurrence, an event both anxiously awaited and deeply revered. The amount â€¦

entry.title: â€˜A language everyone understandsâ€™: Jordanian cartoonist on art as hope
entry.summary: Cartoons have long been used to provoke thought, raise questions and challenge power, but for Jordanian artist and activist Omar Abdallat, theyâ€™re also a bridge between people.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Aid access and hospital operations remain constrained in Gaza
entry.summary: Aid deliveries into Gaza continue to face difficulties as fighting continues across the territory, with the UN warning that most hospitals are only partially functioning and more than 16,500 patients still require urgent medical evacuation.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Peacebuilding Fund hits $1 billion milestone amid funding gap
entry.summary: The United Nations Peacebuilding Fund on Wednesday announced a major milestone, with the approval of more than $1 billion in support to global peacebuilding and conflict-prevention initiatives since 2020.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Ukraineâ€™s children enter fourth school year under war as 4.6 million face education barriers
entry.summary: This year alone, 4.6 million children in Ukraine are struggling to access education as they endure a fourth academic year under full-scale war.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Defying the odds: Young entrepreneurs vow to take their chances and build the industries of tomorrow
entry.summary: Young people make a vital contribution to the creation of industries that benefit people and the planet. Their role was recognised on Wednesday at Generation Future day of the Global Industry Summit in Riyadh, with commitments to ensure that their voices are heard and their ideas shared more widely.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Somalia declares drought emergency as millions face hunger after failed rains
entry.summary: Somalia is facing a rapidly worsening drought emergency, with vast swaths of the country now parched after four failed rainy seasons, leaving millions at risk of hunger and displacement, UN humanitarians warned on Wednesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: 10 of the best hotels in Dubai
entry.summary:
Considering the city has risen from the desert fairly recently, it has fast become an impressive playground for some of the world's most innovative hotel investors. From laid-back resorts on artificial islands to super-luxurious suites in architectural wonders, Dubaiâ€™s hotel scene is never boring.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Even by the standards of an emirate that shows all the constructional restraint of a toddler with a trunk of Lego, Dubai is in turbocharge mode. Eminent hotel groups are flooding in as superhotels spring up on man-made islands. Yet for all Dubaiâ€™s veneration of the new, decades of innovation have left a legacy of eye-catching and, in some cases, surprisingly affordable sanctuaries in which to bed down, whether youâ€™re â€¦

entry.title: The ultimate guide to Custer State Park
entry.summary:
The wild heart of South Dakota, Custer State Park rivals many of Americaâ€™s national parks in scope and splendour. Just a 30-minute drive from the iconic faces of Mount Rushmore, youâ€™ll discover some of the most distinct landscapes in the American West. Set deep in the Black Hills, the park is renowned for its granite peaks, sparkling lakes and one of the largest publicly owned bison herds in the world, with over 1,400 of these magnificent creatures roaming freely across the valleys. Though it offers all visitors twisting highways and world-class hiking trails, it especially rewards those who choose to stay longer and travel deeper. Hereâ€™s how to do just that.
Start your adventure from behind the wheel. Set off early on the southern end of the Needles Highway, a 14-mile marvel that sâ€¦

entry.title: Scientists are hunting for the sixth basic taste
entry.summary:
In recent years, scientists have proposed a few contenders for a sixth taste that would join the ranks of sweet, salty, sour, bitter, and umami. But making the case for the discovery of a new taste is more complicated than you might think. Could â€œfattyâ€ or â€œstarchyâ€ one day become accepted as the sixth basic taste alongside the likes of sweet and salty?
In 1908, Japanese chemist Kikunae Ikeda was studying the active substances in kombu (seaweed), when he made a discovery that would change food science forever. Ikeda realized that a compound called glutamic acid was what gave seaweed such a distinct savory and meaty tasteâ€”nothing like the existing basic tastes of sweet, salty, sour, and bitter. He dubbed that taste umami.
Yet even though people have been eating seaweed, mushrooâ€¦

entry.title: Inside Austin, the Texas city that prides itself on staying weird
entry.summary:
Even though Austin was, until 2024, the fastest-growing US city for 12 consecutive years â€” the city has managed the near-impossible feat of preserving its free-spirited, rebellious vibe. The Texan capital marches to its own beat, from nightly bat-spotting to food trucks that rival fine-dining restaurants. This quirky vibe is what makes it so magnetic.
This article was produced byÂ National Geographic TravellerÂ (UK).
â€˜Keep Austin weirdâ€™. Youâ€™re bound to see the cityâ€™s slogan within a day of touching down in the Texan capital. Whether on a sticker, a mural or someoneâ€™s T-shirt, it appears as if summoned to bring visitors on board. After all, Austinites are proud of their home just the way it is â€” a little bit wacky but with a whole lotta heart.
While the skyscrapered Downtâ€¦

entry.title: Among manta rays and sea turtles, a journey of wonder unfolds
entry.summary:
National Geographic photographer Josh Cogan has spent years documenting cultures, landscapes, and people in motion. But itâ€™s not just action that captures his attention. Itâ€™s the stillness between movements: the quiet pause before someone decides to take a step, try something new, or step into the unknown. Thatâ€™s what brought him to Hawaiiâ€™s Big Island. And thatâ€™s what he saw in his travel companion, Joey.
Joey, a former law enforcement officer and firefighter, has a large tattoo of a sea turtle on his left calf. Even when he wears shorts, though, the turtle is often hidden by the brace he wears to help him walk.Â
Since the onset of his symptoms related to CIDP (chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy), a rare autoimmune condition, Joey experienced increasing difficultyâ€¦

entry.title: 5 myths about male fertility
entry.summary:
Despite increases awareness about male fertility issues and better tests and treatments, myths often put more blame on the egg (red in the microscope image above) rather than sperm (blue). Should men trying to have kids avoid hot tubs? Do boxers vs. briefs impact sperm counts? Here's the real science behind male fertility.
Roughly 15 percent of American couples have trouble conceiving. Until as recently as a decade ago, the focus fell squarely on the woman. Men avoided seeing a doctor, fertility experts say, or, if they were dragged in by their partner, silently prayed the problem wasnâ€™t theirs.
In many cases, â€œit's a virility thing,â€ with men erroneously fusing fertility with masculinity, says Stan Honig, a urologist and chief of reproductive and sexual medicine at the Yale Uâ€¦

entry.title: Orangutan adopts little sister after their mother's death
Tension after builders discover an ancient Minoan ruin on Crete
entry.summary:
Archaeologists speculate that this recently found ancient Minoan labyrinthian monument could have been used for rituals. It was found on the same hill selected for a new airport radar tower, a development that some say will jeopardize the integrity of the historical site. As Greece builds to accommodate a rise in tourism and other development projects, unearthed antiquities complicate progress.
Athens, GreeceOn a Cretan hilltop, work to build a new international airport has revealed something extraordinary: a 4,000-year-old labyrinthine monument, resembling a giant wheel, now at the heart of Greeceâ€™s latest battle between developers and historians.
As Greeceâ€™s largest island, Crete draws millions of visitors annually, not only for its pristine beaches and rugged mountains but â€¦

entry.title: Over 600 million children exposed to violence at home, UNICEF warns
entry.summary: More than one in four children globally â€“ around 610 million â€“ live with mothers who have experienced physical, emotional or sexual abuse by an intimate partner in the past year, making violence a part of their everyday lives, according to new data released by the UN Childrenâ€™s Fund (UNICEF) on Tuesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: On International Day of Solidarity, UN urges greater support and aid for Palestinians
entry.summary: For over two years, tens of thousands of people have been killed in Gaza. The enclave faces its most severe economic collapse in history, and even amid a fragile ceasefire, children continue to die.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: World News in Brief: Justice efforts in Libya, deadly attacks in Ukraine, scores killed since Israel-Lebanon ceasefire
entry.summary: RecentÂ months have seen progress towards accountability in Libya, the Deputy Prosecutor of the International Criminal Court (ICC) said on Tuesday in a briefing to the UN Security Council.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Violence against women: UN sheds light on global femicide crisis, digital abuse
entry.summary: For three years, thousands of angry messages poured intoÂ AmericanÂ actressÂ Azie Tesfaiâ€™s phone from a manÂ sheâ€™dÂ never seen nor met.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Nigeria: Hundreds abducted in the north as insurgent attacks rise
entry.summary: Authorities in Nigeria are being urged to investigate the wave of abductions in the West African country, where attacks by insurgent groups are increasing.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Why a woman is killed every 10 minutes; the rising wave of global femicide
entry.summary: Every 10 minutes, partners and family members killed a woman intentionally in 2024 and that trend is growing, according to the UN.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Global HIV response facing worst setback in decades, UNAIDS warns
entry.summary: The global response to HIV is facing its most serious setback in decades, UNAIDS warned on Tuesday, as abrupt funding cuts and a deteriorating human rights environment disrupt prevention and treatment services across dozens of countries.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Despite ongoing discrimination, women entrepreneurs are reshaping the Global South, with crucial support from the UN
entry.summary: Exceptional women business leaders such as African engineer-turned-entrepreneur Norah Magero are demonstrating how lived experience and ingenuity, backed by United Nations support, can turn promising ideas into successful companies, even in societies where their voices have long been sidelined.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Gaza women are â€˜last line of protectionâ€™ for their families amid attacks, hunger and harsh winter
entry.summary: Women in Gaza are ensuring their familiesâ€™ survival â€œwith nothing but courage and exhausted handsâ€ while violence continues and essentials remain in short supply, the UNâ€™s gender equality agency warned on Tuesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Gaza facing worst economic collapse ever recorded, UN trade agency warns
entry.summary: The Occupied Palestinian Territory is now in its deepest economic crisis ever recorded, with Gaza suffering an â€œunprecedented and catastrophicâ€ collapse, according to a new report from the UN Conference on Trade and Development (UNCTAD) presented in Geneva on Tuesday.

entry.title: From Mentoring to Refusing to Stay Silent: Strategies for Women in Investigative Journalism
entry.summary: Women investigative reporters face harassment, surveillance, and personal risk. Here are practical strategies to confront these challenges from female journalists on the front lines.

entry.title: Methodology
entry.summary: Ipsos KnowledgePanel and Omnibus methodology Introduction Ipsos delivers affordable, statistically valid online research through KnowledgePanel. KnowledgePanel is the first and largest online research panel that is representative of the entire U.S. population. Panel members are randomly recruited through probability-based sampling, and households are provided with access to the Internet and hardware if needed. Ipsos recruits [â€¦] The post Methodology appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Acknowledgments
entry.summary: This report is a collaborative effort based on the input and analysis of the following individuals. Jacob Poushter, Associate Director, Global Attitudes ResearchJordan Lippert, Research AnalystSofia Hernandez Ramones, Research Assistant Julia Armeli, Research AssistantDorene Asare-Marfo, Senior Panel ManagerPeter Bell, Associate Director, Design and ProductionJanakee Chavda, Associate Digital ProducerLaura Clancy, Research AnalystManolo Corichi, Research AnalystJonathan Evans, [â€¦] The post Acknowledgments appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: German Views of the U.S.-Germany Relationship Turn Sharply Negative
entry.summary: Nearly three-quarters of German adults say relations with the United States are bad, while only 24% of U.S adults say the same of relations with Germany. The post German Views of the U.S.-Germany Relationship Turn Sharply Negative appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Methodology
entry.summary: The American Trends Panel survey methodology Overview Data in this report comes from Wave 181 of the American Trends Panel (ATP), Pew Research Centerâ€™s nationally representative panel of randomly selected U.S. adults. The survey was conducted from Oct. 6 to Oct. 16, 2025. A total of 8,046 panelists responded out of 12,845 who were sampled, [â€¦] The post Methodology appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Acknowledgments
entry.summary: This report was written by Carolyne Im, research analyst, and Luis NoÃ©-Bustamante, research associate. Editorial guidance was provided by Mark Hugo Lopez, director, race and ethnicity research; Sahana Mukherjee, associate director, race and ethnicity research; Steven Shepard, associate director, political research; and Hannah Hartig, senior researcher, political research. The report was reviewed by Neha Sahgal, [â€¦] The post Acknowledgments appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Appendix: Supplemental tables
entry.summary: The post Appendix: Supplemental tables appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 6. Latinosâ€™ experiences with immigration enforcement in the second Trump administration
entry.summary: Amid heightened deportation efforts during Donald Trumpâ€™s second term, about half of U.S. Latinos worry they or someone close to them might be deported, up from earlier in the year. A majority also say immigration arrests or raids have occurred in their local area in the past six months. Latinos are more likely than other [â€¦] The post 6. Latinosâ€™ experiences with immigration enforcement in the second Trump administration appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 5. What Latinos think about the Trump administrationâ€™s deportation efforts
entry.summary: U.S. Latinos mostly oppose the Trump administrationâ€™s immigration policy. Roughly two-thirds say they disapprove of the administrationâ€™s approach to immigration, and about seven-in-ten say the administration is doing too much when it comes to deporting immigrants who are living in the United States illegally. Compared with all U.S. adults, Latinos express more critical views. Although [â€¦] The post 5. What Latinos think about the Trump administrationâ€™s deportation efforts appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 4. Latinosâ€™ ratings of the U.S. economy and their top economic concerns
entry.summary: Ahead of the 2024 presidential election, Latino voters ranked the economy as the top issue in their vote. Meanwhile, Donald Trump made improving economic conditions a central part of his campaign message. But nearly a year into Trumpâ€™s second term, most Latinos rate the economy negatively. And 61% say that Trumpâ€™s policies have made the [â€¦] The post 4. Latinosâ€™ ratings of the U.S. economy and their top economic concerns appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 3. The state of Latinosâ€™ finances: Outlook, experiences, preparedness for a financial downturn
entry.summary: U.S. government data shows that Hispanicsâ€™ financial situation has improved in some ways. Between 2023 and 2024, the median income of Hispanic households increased by 5.5%, and the poverty rate among Hispanics decreased from 16.6% to 15.0%.[10.numoffset=â€10â€³ These are estimates published by the U.S. Census Bureau based on the 2024 Current Population Survey (CPS) and [â€¦] The post 3. The state of Latinosâ€™ finances: Outlook, experiences, preparedness for a financial downturn appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 2. How Latinos see their groupâ€™s situation in the U.S.
entry.summary: For the first time in nearly two decades of Pew Research Centerâ€™s surveys of Hispanics, most say they think the situation of U.S. Hispanics has worsened in the last year. And about a third of Latinos say that in the last six months they have considered leaving the country, with the top reason being the [â€¦] The post 2. How Latinos see their groupâ€™s situation in the U.S. appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 1. How Latinos assess Trump and his impact on U.S. Hispanics
entry.summary: More Latinos disapprove than approve of the way Donald Trump is handling his job as president, and most say his administrationâ€™s policies have been harmful to Hispanics. Additionally, about three-in-four Latinos are dissatisfied with the way things are going in the country today. These views come nearly one year after Trump was reelected to office. [â€¦] The post 1. How Latinos assess Trump and his impact on U.S. Hispanics appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Majorities of Latinos Disapprove of Trump and His Policies on Immigration, Economy
entry.summary: 78% of Hispanics say Trumpâ€™s policies harm their group, but views of the president and policies differ widely by how they voted in 2024. The post Majorities of Latinos Disapprove of Trump and His Policies on Immigration, EconomyÂ appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: A journey to Hawaii yields a new perspective
entry.summary:
In Hawaiâ€™i Volcanoes National Park, the landscape is constantly evolving. KÄ«lauea, one of the most active volcanoes on Earth, breathes steam and sulfur into the rainforest canopy. Lava rockâ€”new land formed by past eruptionsâ€”crunches underfoot.
For National Geographic photographer Josh Cogan, this spot is one of many on the Big Island that invites both exploration and reflection.
"There's no place like the Big Island," he says, noting that it's both the largest and newest of Hawaii's islands. "There's all this possibility of evolution and change in the landscape. Transformation is constantly happening here."
Recently, Josh traveled around the Big Island with Joey, a lifelong adventurer and former first responder who lives with CIDP (chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneurâ€¦

entry.title: Maltaâ€™s mysterious â€˜fat ladiesâ€™ lure a new generation of pilgrims
entry.summary:
Spiritual pilgrimsâ€”mostly womenâ€”travel to Malta to meditate, chant, and see the temples. A steady stream of spiritual pilgrimsâ€”mostly womenâ€”are drawn to the islandâ€™s ancient temples and its museums, home to the curvaceous prehistoric figurines seen as symbols of creation and renewal
My gaze follows the spirals carved into the rock, and I feel an inexplicable pull. Within Maltaâ€™s Ä¦al-Tarxien temple complex, the honey-hued stones curve and breathe like living forms, each line hinting at an ancient purpose. Only gradually do I sense the depth of what this place representsâ€”and the controversies that swirl around it. Â
Some believe Maltaâ€™s early Mediterranean culture honored the life-giving forces of womanhood and Earth, its rituals shaped by reverence for fertility and creation. Tâ€¦

entry.title: 7 architectural gems to see in Barcelonaâ€”from GaudÃ­ and beyond
entry.summary:
When visiting Barcelona, visitors should see the work of the famous architect Antoni GaudÃ­, such as Casa Mila, but there are many other architectural wonders to explore in the city. GaudÃ­'s creationsâ€”including his Sagrada Familiaâ€”dominate the conversation. But the 2026 World Capital of Architecture has a range of styles to marvel, from medieval to modern.
Barcelona is the birthplace of Catalan Modernisme, an architectural style characterized by curved lines and fluid shapes, ornamentation inspired by nature, and by the expression of national symbols, such as Cataloniaâ€™s patron Saint George. â€œCatalan Modernisme developed right after the 1888 Universal Exposition,â€ saysÂ Dr. Mireia Freixa, emeritus professor of art history at the University of Barcelona. â€œIt developed as an original nâ€¦

entry.title: The brief lifeâ€”and untimely deathâ€”of Hamnet Shakespeare
entry.summary: This illustration shows William Shakespeare reciting his play Hamlet to his family. His son, Hamnet, stands over his left shoulder and listens, despite the play being written after his death. Though little is known about the life of William Shakespeare's only son, historians say his premature death may have shaped the bard's most famous works. Romeo and Juliet,Â King Lear,Â Hamletâ€”William Shakespeare wrote some of the worldâ€™s best tragedies,Â and heÂ also experienced his own: the death of his 11-year-old son Hamnet.Â Â  Documentary evidence about the boy is thin. â€œThere are three bare facts known about Hamnet,â€ saysÂ Edel Semple, senior lecturer in Shakespeare studies at University College Cork in Ireland. â€œHe was baptized February 2, 1585,Â he was a twin, and he was buried Augâ€¦

entry.title: These mountain resorts are making a differenceâ€”hereâ€™s how
entry.summary:
Les Muiners ski lifts are powered by renewable energy and various technologies allow the resort to save up to 8% in fuel and 15% in artificial snow production. With Northern Hemisphere mountain towns getting ready to open their slopes for the winter season, we shine a light on resorts that are cutting their carbon footprint with innovations in transport and ski kit.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
With winters getting less predictable in mountains worldwide, ski resorts are looking to future-proof their seasons. Many have thrown themselves into the business of cutting their carbon emissions, as well as making activities more sustainable in other ways. Meanwhile, we, the travelling public, can do a lot more than cheer them on. How we get to a â€¦

entry.title: The 30-foot sea cow quickly hunted to extinction because of its tasty meat
entry.summary:
Illustration of the extinct Steller's Sea Cow (Hydrodamalis gigas), a sirenian that lived in the Bering Sea and was hunted to extinction in the 1700s. The Steller's Sea Cow is related to the manatee and the dugong.


Few complete skeletons remain of this gentle behemoth, who was destroyed by explorers and fur traders in the Arctic. On November 8, 1741, naturalist Georg Wilhelm Steller walked along the shores of an unnamed island. He had ended up in that desolate place as part of Vitus Beringâ€™s expedition, whose goal was to discover a sea route from Siberia to America. The crew succeeded in their mission and reached the Alaskan coast â€” but on their return voyage, disaster struck. Their ship was wrecked, and they found themselves stranded on a barren, uninhabited island thaâ€¦

entry.title: Are foxes becoming domesticated?
entry.summary:
An urban red fox wanders on top of a brick wall. People who see evidence of â€œself-domesticationâ€ in foxes are confusing it with habituation, experts say. Videos of friendly, gentle foxes approaching humans, seemingly wanting to play, are going viral on TikTok. But just because a species is sociable doesn't necessarily make it domesticated.
In a video with over one million views on TikTok, a wild fox plays with what appears to be a ball, letting it roll down a hilly slope and chasing after it. The video is tagged #domesticatedfox. â€œHe probably watched dogs playing fetch from afar,â€ one commenter writes. â€œHe just wants to be a good boy too.â€Â In another TikTok, a wild fox approaches a humanâ€™s outstretched hand. An enamored commenter jokes: "If not pet, why pet-shaped?"
A slew ofâ€¦

entry.title: The woman who almost became Englandâ€™s first queen
entry.summary:
When the sinking of the White ShipÂ decimated Englandâ€™s line of succession and threw the kingdom into chaosÂ in 1120, one teenage girl was the only heir to the British throne left standing.Â
Even with theâ€”at first reluctantâ€”endorsement of her father King Henry I, 25-year-old MatildaÂ couldnâ€™t achieve that historical first: ruling as queen in her own right.Â
Hereâ€™s how Matildaâ€™s pathâ€”and, perhaps, a crucial â€œlack of ruthlessnessâ€â€”led to her almost being the first queen of England.Â
In 1112, when she was just eight years old, King Henry I shipped Matilda off to Germany to marry Henry V of Germany, the Holy Roman Emperor. She cut her teeth in the German court, learning how to survive away from her powerful family. These years strengthened her â€œcore of steel,â€ says Catherine â€¦

entry.title: Some people are always late. Science can explain why.
entry.summary:
Some people just seem wired to be running behindâ€”and experts say that may actually be true. Behavioral science has identified five major drivers of habitual lateness, from the planning fallacy to your sleep chronotype. Are you a multitasker, a free spirit, or an overly optimistic planner? Experts say these are some of the traits that explain why some people are always running behind.
If youâ€™re one of those people whose â€œIâ€™ll be there in fiveâ€ reliably turns into 15, youâ€™re not aloneâ€”and youâ€™re not necessarily careless or inconsiderate, either. Most of us have been late at some point, but some people find themselves constantly running behind.
That discrepancy often begs the question: why do some people seem wired to be late while others treat punctuality like a personal law? â€¦

entry.summary: The Security Council is meeting against the backdrop of Gazaâ€™s fragile ceasefire, with ambassadors expected to urge Israel and Hamas to stick to their commitments amid renewed violence and deepening humanitarian needs. entry.title: Overcoming Four Big Challenges to Investigating the Water Crisis
entry.summary: Journalists reporting on water scarcity often confront the same four barriers: lack of transparency, limited access to sites and sources, complex and unwieldy data, and a resistant media environment.

entry.title: Best Reporting and Business Practices for Freelance Investigative Journalists
entry.summary: At GIJC25, veteran freelancers from Africa, Asia, and Europe shared tips for finding funding, managing security, and negotiating with editors over rates, commissions, and deadlines.

entry.title: Nobel Laureate Urges Journalists to Investigate the Systems and Enablers that Foster Corruption Worldwide
entry.summary: In a keynote conversation, the economist said reporters have a key role to play in probing Western financial institutions and the rules that lead to wealth being laundered from the Global South.

entry.title: In 2027, Global Investigative Journalism Conference Heads to the Netherlands
entry.summary: The 15th Global Investigative Journalism Conference will be held in 2027 in the Netherlands, co-hosted by GIJN and VVOJ (The Dutch-Flemish Association of Investigative Journalists).

entry.title: The best of Florida's Gulf Coast beaches, and beyond
entry.summary:
Fringed by the blue-green waters of the Gulf of Mexico, St Pete-Clearwater is renowned for its long stretches of white, powder-soft sand and a climate that promises more sunshine than most places in the US. But beyond its glistening shoreline, this laid-back Floridian peninsula offers a mix of art-centric cities, nature parks and a flourishing craft beer scene â€” making it just as rewarding inland as it is along the coast.
In downtown St. Petersburg, just seven miles from the beach, independent breweries sit alongside major institutions such as The DalÃ­ Museum and the Museum of Fine Arts. Just a short distance away on nearby uninhabited islands, boardwalk trails weave through mangrove thickets and pine forests, offering a glimpse of the regionâ€™s wilder side.
Here are five mustâ€¦

entry.title: Why winter is the perfect time to visit this coastal UK town
entry.summary:
Southwest UKâ€™s famous summer destination St Ives becomes an equally inviting retreat in winter months with museums, restaurants and plenty of gin. This Cornish town is a summertime darling, but its captivating galleries and atmospheric jazz bars make it equally inviting in the winter months.
This article was produced byÂ National Geographic TravellerÂ (UK).
On the clearest days, St Ives seems like a trick of the eye. All golden beaches and cliffs etched with whitewashed cottages, it feels more like an Italian fishing village than an English coastal town. That incongruity has made the Cornish enclave one of Britianâ€™s most popular summer escapes, but its charms donâ€™t fade as winter sets in. Rather than hibernating, the town exhales. Its cobblestoned streets see less footfall, whâ€¦

entry.summary: Vaccine alliance Gavi and childrenâ€™s agency UNICEF have struck a new pricing deal that will sharply cut the cost of a key malaria vaccine and make it possible to protect nearly seven million additional children by 2030, the agencies announced on Sunday.

entry.title: Brave Investigations from Nigeria, Egypt, Peru, and Mexico Honored at GIJC25â€™s Global Shining Light Awards
entry.summary: These three winners and recipient of a special citation represent outstanding journalism from developing or transitioning countries, carried out under threat or in perilous conditions.

entry.title: Newsroom Instincts, Scholarly Patience: How to Conduct Ethnographic Journalism
entry.summary: Ethnographic journalism blends anthropological theory and immersive fieldwork to report on marginalized communities, but its relationship with traditional journalism remains contested.

entry.title: Expert Advice to Keep Your Sources and Whistleblowers Safe
entry.summary: Keeping your sources, your data, and yourself safe during investigations is a complex undertaking. Four veteran journalists offer their tips on how to do so.

entry.title: Why Edinburgh is Europe's ultimate escape for book-lovers
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Itâ€™s a dark, dreich night in Edinburghâ€™s Grassmarket, but the mood upstairs at the Beehive Inn is anything but bleak. The snug room above the pub has been packed tight, with rows of mismatched chairs creaking under the weight of an expectant crowd before an empty stage. The air is warm and close, carrying the faint scent of beer and damp coats slung over seats, and the murmur of excited conversation.
Iâ€™m here for the Edinburgh Literary Pub Tour, an evening stroll through the gothic Old Townâ€™s winding wynds and hallowed inns that bring this cityâ€™s remarkable literary legacy to life. Last year marked 20 years since Edinburgh became the worldâ€™s first UNESCO City of Literature, a celebration of the wealth of writers whâ€¦

entry.title: BelÃ©m COP30 delivers climate finance boost and a pledge to plan fossil fuel transition
entry.summary: In a pivotal outcome at COP30 in BelÃ©m, Brazil, countries agreed on a sweeping package to scale up climate finance and accelerate implementation of the Paris Agreement â€“ but without a clear commitment to move away from fossil fuels.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: From silence to strength: Women leaders speak out in South Sudan
entry.summary: Scolded for wanting to go to school as a girl and dismissed or ignored as an adult, Awrelia from Wau in South Sudan has learnt to advocate for herself, her children and for the women in her community.

entry.title: Nigeria: Schools should be â€˜sanctuaries not targetsâ€™ says deputy UN chief following latest mass abduction
entry.summary: The UN Deputy Secretary-General voiced deep alarm on Saturday over the latest mass abduction from a school in Nigeria, calling for the immediate release of those taken.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: â€˜Leave no one behindâ€™: As wealth gap widens, UN calls for new industrial deal for worldâ€™s poorest
entry.summary: Ministers and leaders from across the worldâ€™s 44 least developed countries have pledged to accelerate industrialisation that benefits all, and strengthen resilience in the face of global challenges, at an international UN conference in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia.

entry.title: Exploring Peruâ€™s hidden corners
entry.summary:
Peruâ€™s archaeological riches have made it one of South Americaâ€™s most enthralling destinations. However, itâ€™s also a place of world-class gastronomy, superlative hiking trails and rugged islands teeming with marine wildlife, from squawking sea birds to roaring sea lions. If youâ€™re fascinated by ancient history, itching to hike through high-altitude Andean scenery or curious to see places untroubled by crowds, the little-known Peruvian regions of Ancash, Ica and Amazonas offer a broad canvas for adventure. Hereâ€™s a glimpse of what awaits off the beaten path. Â
While Peru is renowned for its ancient architecture, many of its most fascinating structures remain off visitorsâ€™ radars. ChavÃ­n de HuÃ¡ntar, a magnificent 3,000-year-old temple complex, is a four-hour drive from the Ancash capiâ€¦

entry.title: How to Investigate the Impact of Global Energy Companies on Local Public Health
entry.summary: Multimedia investigations across Africa and the Middle East highlight the links between environmental damage and public health, while seeking to expose who is responsible for the harm.

entry.title: Strategies for Covering Asia in a Shrinking Civic Space for Independence and Accountability
entry.summary: An All-Asian GIJC25 keynote panel discussed how the continent's reporters have bravely exposed corruption scandals while facing exile, harassment, attacks, and threats of imprisonment.

entry.title: Tips for Identifying New Funding Sources for Investigative Journalism
entry.summary: Nonprofit news outlets must put extra emphasis on audience engagement, out-of-the-box solutions, and communicating to potential donors their unique value to democracy.

entry.title: Pivoting to Podcasts? How Print Journalists Can Become Audio Storytellers
entry.summary: Narrative podcasts have become a transformative tool for investigative reporting. In a session at the GIJC, veteran audio editors and producers unpacked why and how investigative journalists can tap into its power.

entry.title: Why capsule hotels are taking global cities by storm
entry.summary:
The Zedwell capsule hotel in London's Piccadilly Circus is the largest of its kind in the world. What started out as minimalist sleeping pods for Japanese salarymen has morphed into an urban hospitality trend, with London leading the charge.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
It may sound like an oxymoron, but the biggest capsule hotel in the world has just opened in central London. The Zedwell, in Piccadilly Circus, offers 1,000 sound-proofed, windowless â€˜cocoonsâ€™, with prices from as little as Â£30 a night. A raft of other hotels drawing on the same low-space, low-cost concept is set to arrive in the capital in the coming years, serving as the catalyst â€” insiders believe â€” for a global proliferation. Novel, affordable, convenient and fun, the aâ€¦

entry.title: New treasures hint at what Britain was like before Roman conquest
entry.summary:
Late in 2021, a man running a metal detector over the muddy fields of northern Britain got a hit. Rather than picking up a shovel and digging out his treasure, he decided to phone Tom Moore, an archaeologist whoâ€™s worked extensively on the local landscape. Moore and his team came to inspect the find and unearthed more than 900 objects, an enormous trove, that had been piled in a ditch in the waning days of the British Iron Age (ca 750 B.C. to A.D. 43), sometime around the time of the birth of Christ.Â Â
Pieces of horse harness, dozens of iron tires, hefty spears, a cauldron, parts of chariots or wagons, ornate jewelry, a large iron mirror, and what may be a wine mixing bowl were all deposited in whatâ€™s now Yorkshireâ€”left there for mysterious reasons. The objects were luxurious for theiâ€¦

entry.title: The oldest known city map is startlingly precise
entry.summary:
Archaeologists from the University of Pennsylvania began the first full excavation of the Mesopotamian city of Nippur in 1899. This photo from that year was taken atop a pyramid-like ziggurat, near the remains of a temple known as the Ekur. It took decades for archaeologists to realize this 3,500-year-old tablet depicts an ancient city at scale. But how did its creators pull that off?
One of the worldâ€™s oldest maps was etched into a clay tablet likely sometime between 1500 and 1300 B.C. And ever since its discovery, during an 1899 excavation in whatâ€™s now Iraq, scholars have argued over how to read it. A bit larger than an adult hand, the map shows distances between gates in the wall surrounding the Mesopotamian city of Nippur. But to some archaeologistsâ€™ eâ€¦

entry.title: Where to go for a quiet Iceland escape? Try the Troll Peninsula
entry.summary:
The scenic road to SiglufjÃ¶rÃ°ur from Akureyri skirts the narrow EyjafjÃ¶rÃ°ur in places and offers breathtaking scenes of Iceland's arctic landscapes. Take a winter road trip from Icelandâ€™s second city, Akureyri, through a northern peninsula framed by fjords and punctuated by isolated herring-fishing villages.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
In winter, the Troll Peninsula is a place where people come to be alone. Silence hovers over the piebald mountains, as thick as fog. Ice cracks audibly on the surface of fjords as solitary boats putter in and out of frosty harbours. The roads â€” not that there are many â€” feel empty. But thereâ€™s a quiet beauty in TrÃ¶llaskagi, this sliver of land on Icelandâ€™s frayed north coast. And though it feels isolated, â€¦

entry.title: At Hawaiiâ€™s former leprosy colony, a rare glimpse into history
entry.summary:
On MolokaÊ»i, Kalaupapa National Historical Park (on the Kalaupapa Peninsula) has reopened, offering a limited number of visitors the opportunity to take a uniquely personal guided tour with the residents of a former leprosy colony. Kalaupapa National Historic Park on MolokaÊ»iâ€™s remote north shore now offers visitors a deeply personal tour of what was once an isolated quarantine zone.
For the first time in more than five years, visitors can now return to one of Americaâ€™s least-visited national park sites in HawaiÊ»i. Closed since March 2020,Â Kalaupapa National Historic ParkÂ is open again, albeit under strict limitations, with the introduction of a brand-new tour that offers travelers a rare glimpse into a powerful, ongoing chapter of Hawaiian history.Â
Even before the pandemic câ€¦

entry.title: What was Britain like before the Roman conquest? New treasures hold clues.
entry.summary:
Late in 2021, a man running a metal detector over the muddy fields of northern Britain got a hit. Rather than picking up a shovel and digging out his treasure, he decided to phone Tom Moore, an archaeologist whoâ€™s worked extensively on the local landscape. Moore and his team came to inspect the find and unearthed more than 900 objects, an enormous trove, that had been piled in a ditch in the waning days of the British Iron Age (ca 750 B.C. to A.D. 43), sometime around the time of the birth of Christ.Â Â
Pieces of horse harness, dozens of iron tires, hefty spears, a cauldron, parts of chariots or wagons, ornate jewelry, a large iron mirror, and what may be a wine mixing bowl were all deposited in whatâ€™s now Yorkshireâ€”left there for mysterious reasons. The objects were luxurious for theiâ€¦

entry.title: The race to save secrets trapped in ice
entry.summary:
In the summer of 2022,Â a small but bustling town appeared atop the normally barren Greenland ice sheet. Rows of red tents flapped in the wind, and an LC-130 Hercules cargo plane occasionally delivered food, fuel, and equipment. But the campâ€™s main activity lay hidden 30 feet below the surface, in a network of tunnels that workers had spent weeks chainsawing into the ice.
Researchers bundled in down jackets toiled around the clock in these snowy tunnels as a massive drill rig churned downward to extract core samples and the secrets they contain from the deepest recesses of the ice sheet below.
Some of these cylindrical ice coresâ€”each about the width of a pool noodleâ€”hadnâ€™t seen daylight for 100,000 years. Theyâ€™re clear and flawless, â€œlike window glass,â€ says JÃ¸rgen Peder Steffenseâ€¦

entry.title: UN presents UN80 Initiative Action Plan, setting coordinated path for system-wide reforms
entry.summary: The United Nations outlined how it intends to advance one of its most comprehensive system-wide reform efforts in decades, as Under-Secretary-General for Policy Guy Ryder presented the UN80 Initiative Action Plan. The plan brings the Secretary-Generalâ€™s major UN80 reform proposals into a single, coherent structure to streamline efforts that will make the UN system deliver better.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN decries â€˜truly horrificâ€™ massacres in DR Congo
entry.summary: Seventeen civilians, including women in labour and patients receiving care, were slaughtered inside a Catholic Church-run health centre in eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) last week.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: From waste pickers to courtrooms: Women demand a gender focus at COP30
entry.summary: On the scheduled final day of COP30 in BelÃ©m, tense negotiations are stretching into Friday afternoon as divisions persist. Amid the ongoing talks, one message is cutting through the noise: there is no climate justice without gender equality.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Itâ€™s time for leadership and vision, Guterres tells G20 in South Africa
entry.summary: A South African flag-coloured King Protea flower â€“ symbolising hope and regeneration â€“ is the chosen logo for this yearâ€™s G20 Leadersâ€™ Summit, taking place on African soil for the first time.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Can industrial growth and climate action go hand in hand?
entry.summary: Do higher living standards in developing countries have to mean more polluting, fossil-fuel dependent industries? Or is a low-carbon alternative possible? As the world grapples with climate change, economic inequality, and rapid technological shifts, next weekâ€™s Global Industry Summit will tackle these questions, bringing together governments, business leaders, and innovators to shape solutions that balance prosperity with sustainability.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Gaza: Two children killed every day during fragile ceasefire, says UNICEF
entry.summary: Ongoing attacks and airstrikes attributed to Israeli forces in Gaza continue to kill and maim people of all ages in the shattered enclave despite an agreed ceasefire, UN agencies said on Friday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Not in our name
entry.summary: The gravest of all decisions, to go to war, happens without the consent of the people. This is a great flaw in democracy - by Vincenza Falletti Read on Aeon

entry.title: Investigating Illegal Mining: Tips on Angles, Sourcing, and Post-Publication
entry.summary: Experts on reporting on illegal mining in Zimbabwe, Brazil, and Turkey shared tips on building sources on the ground, establishing trust, and telling a well-rounded story.

entry.title: Video: Why have polls underestimated Donald Trump?
entry.summary: Weâ€™re in an era where the people most likely to respond to a poll are also the most likely to vote Democratic for president. Pew Research Centerâ€™s head methodologist Courtney Kennedy explains how pollsters are tackling this challenge to make samples as representative as possible. The post Video: Why have polls underestimated Donald Trump? appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Exclusive: Inside the new Natural History Museum Abu Dhabi
entry.summary:
The Natural History Museum Abu Dhabi (NHMAD) opens its doors to the public on November 22, joining the ranks of legendary institutionsâ€”New Yorkâ€™s American Museum of Natural History, Pittsburghâ€™s Carnegie Museum of Natural History, Londonâ€™s Natural History Museumâ€”dedicated to telling the story of the planet. National Geographic received exclusive access during NHMADâ€™s final build-out for a first look at some of its world-class installations.
The star of NHMAD is undoubtedly Stan, one of the most complete Tyrannosaurus rex skeletons ever found. The 38-foot skeleton is made even more awe-inspiring by its display: as part of the first ever depiction of two battling T. rexes. Thatâ€™s just one of the dynamic megafauna showcasesâ€”which include a freshly cleaned blue whale skeleton and a four-tâ€¦

author.name: Nick Martin, Craig Cutler, Samuel Garcia, Craig Cutler

entry.title: We caught a view of comet 3I/ATLAS from Mars
entry.summary:
Ever since the interstellar object 3I/ATLASâ€”the third of its kind ever discoveredâ€”was first spotted back in July, astronomers around the world have avidly tracked it, watching it transform from an ice ball into a bright luminous body as it plunged toward the sun.
But NASA has not commented on the interstellar object or shared any images of it for over aÂ month, due to the longest government shutdown in U.S. history. This silence has been filled with unfounded (and usually zany) ideas about the objectâ€™s nature by celebrities and conspiracy theorists alikeâ€”many of which have speculated, without evidence, that it might be an alien spacecraft.
With the shutdown now over, the space agency was finally able to share its latest shots of the icy interloper at a press conference this week.â€¦

entry.title: The Roman emperor who died from eating too much cheese
entry.summary:
A bust of the Emperor Antoninus Pius, who supposedly perished after bingeing a delectable treat. Lots of emperors met ignominious ends. And then there was Antoninus Pius.
The Roman Empire conjures up images of military power, gladiatorial contests, and feats of engineering, but to the men who ruled, life was complicated and fraught with risk.
Julius Caesar, whose power grabs laid the groundwork for the first Emperor Augustusâ€™s ascent, was not the only would-be tyrant to die violently: some emperors ruled for just a few weeks, while others met sticky ends at the hands of trusted bodyguards and family members. For those who survived, their imperial status gave them the opportunity to indulge their whims and flex their musclesâ€”and their obsessions were often strange indeed. From â€¦

entry.title: What 60 decomposing lizards can tell us about dinosaur death
entry.summary:
One bright day in April 2023, Hannah Maddox drove 13 hours from Knoxville, Tennessee, to a U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) research station in the Everglades National Park, near the southern bump of Florida. Her mission was simple: Collect 30 frozen, dead Argentine black and white dead tegus, culled as part of a broad effort to curtail the invasive lizardsâ€™ spread. The next year, she repeated the journey to collect 30 more.
â€œI did do two cannonball runs to the Everglades and back,â€ she laughs. â€œAnd we thank you for that,â€ says paleoecologist Stephanie Drumheller-Horton, who sent Maddox, a graduate student at the University of Tennessee, to fetch the tegus.
Tegus make adorable pets but destructive members of the Everglades community. â€œThey eat anything they can, including protected â€¦

entry.title: This underrated Louisiana parish is brimming with Cajun culture
entry.summary:
A band member strums the zydeco frottoir while accordion player Nathan Williams plays along during a performance at the Dauphine Club in Parks, a small village in St. Martin's Parish, Louisiana. St. Martin Parish offers a glimpse into the storied heritage of Acadiana, a Louisiana region thatâ€™s renowned for its savory seafood and lively music scene.
With more thanÂ 40 millionÂ visitors recorded in 2024, Louisiana draws domestic and international tourists in droves thanks to its rich cultural heritage, scenic swamps, and thriving seafood scene. To encounter all three, St. Martin Parish is an ideal destination. Established along Louisianaâ€™s Atchafalaya Basin, this storied region offers a glimpse into the idyllic side of the Pelican State, imbued with southern live oaks and tranquilâ€¦

entry.title: Where to travel with the experts in 2026
entry.summary:
Susy Markoe leads healing and reiki experiences at the Ritz-Carlton Maldives, Fari Islands. From culinary safaris to celestial cruises, these 10 luxury trips offer travellers one-of-a-kind experiences guided by some of the worldâ€™s most inspiring minds.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
As demand for expert-led escapes rises, travellers are increasingly looking for trips guided by scientists, historians and creatives. Many tour operators have reported an increase in demand for journeys that offer indulgence as well as insight â€” the likes of meditative healing retreats, chef-led foraging courses, writing workshops and more. Here, we highlight 10 expert-led trips that allow travellers to forge new skills through immersive, educational experiences.â€¦

author.name: Jessica Vincent, Elizabeth Bennett, Mike MacEacheran

entry.title: Doctors are worried about prescribing GLP-1s to certain patients
entry.summary:
GLP-1 drugs such as Ozempic alter hunger signals in the brain, reducing cravings and slowing digestion. For people with a history of eating disorders, those shifts can be both helpful and risky, experts say. With one in eight adults taking drugs like Ozempic and Mounjaro, emerging evidence shows that the medication has potential to both help and harm people with eating disorders.
When Chevese Turner first discussed Ozempic with her doctor to treat her diabetes, she was both worried and relieved. Finally, â€œthere was something effective that [was] going to address my diabetes,â€ says Turner, the CEO of the Body Equity Alliance.
But as a weight discrimination activist, Turner knew how others in her community might view her taking a drug associated with rapid weight loss. She worriâ€¦

entry.title: Where to go stargazing and glamping in southern Utah
entry.summary:
Zion National Park is home to breathtaking red rock canyons and staggering cliffs. With its national parks, slot canyons, and sand dunes, this region of Utah is as geographically diverse as it is awe-inspiring.
The earliest human evidence in southern Utah traces back over 10,000 years, and while a journey here doesnâ€™t exactly feel like traveling back to the Paleolithic period, it can feel like visiting another planet. From the sandstone cliffs of Zion National Park, to the orange sand dunes of Coral Pink Sand Dunes State Park, to the towering hoodoos of Bryce Canyonâ€”southern Utah is an exercise in shape and color. In Grand Staircase-Escalante National Monument, you can squeeze your way through slot canyons by day and marvel at the Milky Way by nightâ€”the state boasts the highest conâ€¦

entry.title: Is cutting back on plastic really worth all the effort?
entry.summary:
While research into the health effects of plastic is ongoing, many experts avoid microwaving food in plastic containers because heat can loosen the bonds holding plastic molecules together. For the average person, trying to avoid plastics can feel overwhelmingâ€”and maybe pointless. Our writer asked two experts how they navigate our plastic-filled world.
Plastic is in our air, food, and water. An estimated 11 million metric tons of plastic end up in the ocean every year, a number expected to triple by 2040. Simultaneously, scientists having been finding microplastics in our brains, lungs, digestive tracts, and even in placentas. But exactly what theyâ€™re doing to our bodies is concerningly unclear. Early research suggests they might be linked to higher risk of heart attack and stroke,â€¦

entry.title: Methodology
entry.summary: 2025 National Public Opinion Reference Survey methodology Summary SSRS conducted the National Public Opinion Reference Survey (NPORS) for Pew Research Center using address-based sampling and a multimode protocol. The survey was fielded from Feb. 5, 2025, to June 18, 2025. Participants were first mailed an invitation to complete an online survey. A paper survey was [â€¦] The post Methodology appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Acknowledgments
entry.summary: This report is a collaborative effort based on the input and analysis of the following individuals. Find related reports online atÂ pewresearch.org/internet. Primary researchers Jeffrey Gottfried, Associate Director, Internet and Technology ResearchÂ Eugenie Park, Research AssistantÂ Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Research teamÂ Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Monica Anderson, Director, Internet and Technology ResearchÂ Â Â Colleen McClain, Senior ResearcherWilliam Bishop, Research AssociateÂ Michelle Faverio, Research AssociateÂ Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Olivia Sidoti, Research Analyst [â€¦] The post Acknowledgments appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Americansâ€™ Social Media Use 2025
entry.summary: YouTube remains the most popular, but adults are increasingly using Instagram, TikTok, WhatsApp and Reddit. Use of some platforms varies by age, gender, and race and ethnicity. The post Americansâ€™ Social Media Use 2025 appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Investigating Global Health: Impact from Corporations

entry.title: Civilian deaths in Ukraine surge past last yearâ€™s toll as winter deepens crisis, Security Council warned
entry.summary: Millions in Ukraine have been left without heating, water or basic public services as winter temperatures plunge â€“ and civilian deaths this year have already surpassed the total for 2024, the UN Security Council heard on Thursday.

entry.summary: Between January and September, over 7,400 cases of gender-based violence (GBV) were reported in Haiti â€“ an average of about 27 per day, according to UN Spokesperson StÃ©phane Dujarric.

entry.title: â€˜The world is watchingâ€™: Guterres and Lula urge unity as COP30 talks near deadline
entry.summary: With the clock ticking on climate negotiations in BelÃ©m, UN Secretary-General AntÃ³nio Guterres and Brazilâ€™s President Luiz InÃ¡cio Lula da Silva, speaking separately, delivered a united message: the world is watching, and compromise cannot wait.

entry.title: Security Council LIVE: Spotlight on rising casualties in Ukraine
entry.summary: The Security Council is holding a rare open briefing on Ukraine following days of deadly attacks by Russia on civilian areas and amid a renewed US mission to Kyiv in search of a peace deal. With attacks on energy infrastructure soaring and civilian casualties climbing, Council members have demanded answers and action. Can the Council increase pressure on veto-wielding Moscow, secure better protection and aid for civilians, and push toward an elusive ceasefire? Follow live below, find full UN meetings coverage here; UN News app users can click here.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Security Councilâ€™s veto power is â€˜poster childâ€™ of global gridlock, says Baerbock
entry.summary: General Assembly President Annalena Baerbock warned on Thursday that repeated deadlock in the Security Council has become the â€œposter childâ€ for wider global gridlock, undermining trust in multilateral institutions.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Whatâ€™s at stake in the COP30 negotiations?
entry.summary: Talks at the COP30 climate summit in BelÃ©m, Brazil, were suspended on Thursday after a fire broke out in the venue, triggering evacuations that halted negotiations between more than 190 delegations. With the summit set to conclude Friday, the disruption came at a critical moment as countries were locked in tense debates over fossil fuels and climate finance. The outcome of these talks is widely seen as a litmus test for turning decades of climate pledges into concrete action.

entry.title: UNICEF: 20% of worldâ€™s children still trapped in extreme poverty
entry.summary: More than 19 per cent of children worldwide live in extreme poverty, surviving on under $3 a day, according to a new UNICEF report.

entry.summary: What was once hailed as a vehicle for empowerment has, for millions of women and girls, become a source of fear.

entry.summary: The lives of people living in Ukraine on the frontline of the war with Russia are becoming more tenuous and support is being provided for those who want to leave as well as those who want to stay in their homes.

entry.title: Taste the seasonâ€”Europe's top Christmas market treats await
entry.summary:
The earliest known recipe for chimney cakes was printed in 18th-century Transylvania. From a bun stuffed with German sausages to a cup of peerless Italian hot chocolate, these are the dishes and drinks worth seeking out during this seasonâ€™s winter festivities.
This article was produced byÂ National Geographic TravellerÂ (UK).
As soon as the first door of advent is flung open, a multitude of pop-up wonderlands start to spring up all over the continent. With their twinkling lights, colourful carousels and towering spruces and firs, Europe's Christmas markets are more than just a visual spectacle â€” their smells and tastes tend to linger longest in visitorsâ€™ memories. Their uniqueness is most evident in their food â€” dishes brimming in regional flavour and loved by locals since chiâ€¦

entry.title: The most underrated Swiss train journeys
entry.summary:
Routes like the Glacier Express may be justly famed, but beyond lie a plethora of overlooked rail itineraries â€” all of which uncover a more surprising side to Switzerland. Think gorgeous Italianate cities, sunlit vineyards and time-capsule towns, where local life proceeds at the same pace it has for centuries. Here's how to plot an alternative tour of this beguiling country.
Best for: all sides of Switzerland
The often-bypassed town of Bellinzona â€” home to three of Switzerlandâ€™s best-preserved medieval castles â€” deserves a linger. After exploring, take the Gotthard Panorama Express north. Boarding this famed train is like stepping into a reel of film, every landscape glimpsed through its windows a new scene. One moment, youâ€™re racing past the palms and piazzas of the Italian-spâ€¦

entry.title: Why rock climbing is the ultimate workout for your body and mind
entry.summary:
A man boulders to the top of the Aguille de Joshua Tree in Joshua Tree National Park. Experts say climbing is a full-body workout that challenges the heart, lungs, brain, and entire musculoskeletal system simultaneously. The sport doesnâ€™t just have physical benefitsâ€”itâ€™s a mental game. â€œRock climbing fires every system of the body and mind.â€
Itâ€™s hard not to be mesmerized by rock climbers as they move up a wall with equal parts power, precision, and calm. Their bodies seem to defy gravityâ€”but whatâ€™s happening inside them may be even more remarkable.
â€œRock climbing fires every system of the body and mind,â€ says Pete Rohleder, a kinesiologist at Kansas State University. â€œIt engages nearly every muscle, challenges your cardiovascular system, and requires laser-focused problem-solâ€¦

entry.title: For a spiritual pilgrimage, head to this tiny Scottish isle
entry.summary:
Baile MÃ²r is the only village on the island of Iona, a Scottish isle that's drawn travelers for centuries. With stunning nature, ancient sacred sites, and a burial ground for kings, the sacredâ€”and car-freeâ€”Isle of Iona is said to be where heaven and Earth meet.
Hemmed by white sand beaches and a bright blue sea, Scotland's Iona pulses on the Atlantic's horizon, where it has captured the imagination of spiritual seekers for centuries, ever since Irish monk Saint Columba washed ashore here with 12 followers in 563 A.D.
The group created a monastery overlooking the coast, which became a "cradle of Christianity" in Scotland, while fostering influential artists and scholars who gave life to poetry, ornate stone carvings, and the monumental, illuminated manuscript known as the Book â€¦

entry.title: Watch orcas team up to hunt great white sharks
entry.summary:
The killer whales ripped the liver out of a shark and passed it aroundâ€”only the second time orcas have been seen engaging in this behavior.
A pod of killer whales chased a young great white shark, immobilized it and then bit its liver out of its body. Researchers documented this rare interaction in the journalÂ Frontiers in Marine Science, representing what they say is the first example of this behavior in the Gulf of California and the second worldwide.
The study adds to a growing body of research on killer whales, also called orcas, hunting great white sharks.
"The footage that they've gotten for this study is incredible,â€™â€™ saysÂ Isabella Reeves, a predator biologist at Flinders University in Adelaide, Australia, who was not involved in the research. Especially is rare iâ€¦

entry.title: The disturbing connection between loneliness and dementia
entry.summary:
Recent research suggests that measuring "social frailty" and weak social connections can be used as a predictor of dementia. Scientists are studying the effect of â€œsocial frailtyâ€ on memory lossâ€”and testing whether AI companions can help.
As people age, frailty starts to creep in. Falls are more damaging and take longer to heal, muscles weaken, walking slows. Â And on top of physical frailty, people can also become â€œsocially frailâ€ as they age as connections to others fade away.
A new study, published in October in the Journal of Gerontology, finds that screening for social frailty might help doctors predict who will get dementia. The authors are now also working to see if an AI companion might help dementia sufferers by giving them an extra boost of social strength.
Physiâ€¦
